title: 1603-D
statement: D. Artistic Partitiontime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test1024 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputFor two positive integers $$$l$$$ and $$$r$$$ ($$$l \\le r$$$) let $$$c(l, r)$$$ denote the number of integer pairs $$$(i, j)$$$ such that $$$l \\le i \\le j \\le r$$$ and $$$\\operatorname{gcd}(i, j) \\ge l$$$. Here, $$$\\operatorname{gcd}(i, j)$$$ is thegreatest common divisor (GCD)of integers $$$i$$$ and $$$j$$$.YouKn0wWho has two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ where $$$1 \\le k \\le n$$$. Let $$$f(n, k)$$$ denote the minimum of $$$\\sum\\limits_{i=1}^{k}{c(x_i+1,x_{i+1})}$$$ over all integer sequences $$$0=x_1 \\lt x_2 \\lt \\ldots \\lt x_{k} \\lt x_{k+1}=n$$$.Help YouKn0wWho find $$$f(n, k)$$$.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 3 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the number of test cases.The first and only line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le n \\le 10^5$$$).OutputFor each test case, print a single integer — $$$f(n, k)$$$.ExampleInput4 6 2 4 4 3 1 10 3Output8 4 6 11NoteIn the first test case, YouKn0wWho can select the sequence $$$[0, 2, 6]$$$. So $$$f(6, 2) = c(1, 2) + c(3, 6) = 3 + 5 = 8$$$ which is the minimum possible.

processed.result:
Given two positive integers $l$ and $r$ ($l \le r$), let $c(l, r)$ denote the number of integer pairs $(i, j)$ such that $l \le i \le j \le r$ and $\text{gcd}(i, j) \ge l$. Here, $\text{gcd}(i, j)$ is the greatest common divisor of integers $i$ and $j$.

You are given two integers $n$ and $k$ where $1 \le k \le n$.  Find the minimum value of $\sum_{i=1}^{k} c(x_i+1, x_{i+1})$ over all integer sequences $0 = x_1 < x_2 < \dots < x_k < x_{k+1} = n$. 

Input:

* The first line contains a single integer $t$ ($1 \le t \le 3 \cdot 10^5$) — the number of test cases.
* The first and only line of each test case contains two integers $n$ and $k$ ($1 \le k \le n \le 10^5$).

Output:

* For each test case, print a single integer — the minimum value of the sum.

Given two numbers,  'n' and 'k', find the smallest sum of values calculated for a specific pattern. The pattern involves dividing 'n' into 'k' parts and calculating a value for each part based on the start and end points of the part.
